# To keep the brain young, safeguard your sleep, study suggests

- Researchers studied a group of adults to learn more about the connection between sleep quality and brain aging.

- The scientists used MRI scans to determine each person’s ‘brain age’ and compared that to sleep patterns.

- They learned that participants with poor sleep had brain ages that were an average of 1 year older than their chronological age.

- This finding was more pronounced in men than in women.

Consistently getting a good night’s sleep seems more important than ever after researchers from the Karolinska Institutet in Sweden published their findings on sleep and brain age.

The scientists analyzed a large group of adults using detailed brain scans to estimate each person’s “brain age.” A person’s brain age should ideally match up with their chronological age.

After going through information provided by the participants about their sleep habits, the researchers learned that people with sleep issues or poor sleep hygiene were more likely to have an advanced brain age.

The findings appear in eBioMedicine.

## Sleep problems impact mood, heart health, inflammation

In the National Health Interview Survey from 2020, 14.5% of adults reported regularly having difficulty sleeping.

People struggle with sleep for many reasons, which can range from insomnia to sleep apnea. Not getting enough rest can have impacts beyond simply feeling sluggish the next day, though.

Some research indicates that chronic sleep issues can impact one’s mood and raise the risk of health issues, such as having a heart attack. The latter likely occurs because poor sleep disrupts the body’s immune system, which can increase inflammation.

The researchers in the new study took a closer look at sleep and brain age by studying more than 27,000 adults in the United Kingdom.

The adults had an average age of around 55 when the study began, and about 54% of the participants were females, and around 46% of the participants were males.

The participants completed a series of questionnaires at the start of the study that covered sleep aspects, such as hours of sleep, daytime sleepiness, and snoring.

The researchers used these responses to determine the sleep scores of the participants and then divided them into three categories:

- healthy sleep patterns (41%)

- intermediate sleep patterns (56%)

- poor sleep patterns (3%).

The researchers also took blood samples at the baseline to check for inflammation markers in the body.

## Poor sleep ages the brain faster

Around 9 years after collecting the participants’ baseline data, they underwent MRI scans to evaluate their brain age. Next, the researchers compared the participants’ brain age to their chronological age.

The researchers found that people with worse sleep scores had a “brain age gap” of 1 year on average.

People with the lowest scores had the biggest gap between their brain age and actual age, with brain aging accelerating by about 6 months for every drop in sleep quality score.

The connection between sleep and brain age was stronger in men than in women, which study author Abigail Dove, PhD, a a postdoctoral researcher in neuroepidemiology at the Aging Research Center at Karolinska, told Medical News Today was a “surprising” find.

Dove told MNT there are a few reasons for this finding, including lifestyle habits:

“It could be that the self-reported measure of sleep used in our study didn’t capture sleep disturbances equally well in men and women. We could also be missing some differences in lifestyle behaviors or drug/medication use between men and women that influences sleep.”

The researchers also found that inflammation explained about 10% of the connection between poor sleep and accelerated brain aging.

“This underscores that inflammation is a major mechanism connecting sleep to brain aging, although it is not the only factor at play,” commented Dove.

Overall, the study shows that sleep may play a key role in maintaining brain health.

## Why brain age acceleration matters

Raj Dasgupta, MD, chief medical advisor for Sleepopolis, who was not involved in this research, spoke with MNT about the study findings.

“This study really underscores something we’ve suspected for a while: poor sleep isn’t just about feeling tired the next day, it can actually affect your brain’s aging,” said Dasgupta. “People with insomnia, snoring, or restless nights may have brains that look older than they really are, which highlights how important good sleep is for long-term cognitive health.”

While a 1-year difference in brain aging may not sound significant at first, Dasgupta noted that “even small changes in brain aging can add up over time.”

For people concerned about their sleep quality and brain aging, Dasgupta shared a few suggestions for improving sleep.

“Stick to a regular sleep schedule, make your bedroom cool, dark, and quiet, limit caffeine or big meals before bed, and try relaxing routines like reading or meditation,” shared Dasgupta. “And if sleep problems persist, talking with a sleep specialist can help identify underlying issues and get you back on track.”

Daniel Truong, MD, neurologist and medical director of the Truong Neuroscience Institute at MemorialCare Orange Coast Medical Center, likewise not involved in the recent study, also spoke with MNT about its finidngs.

“The study you shared makes a strong case that poor sleep accelerates brain aging, with systemic inflammation playing a measurable mediating role,” said Truong.

Truong also commented on the significance of a 1-year difference in brain aging.

“When combined with other risks (hypertension, diabetes, sedentary lifestyle), even modest brain age acceleration can tip someone closer to dementia or cognitive decline,” pointed out Truong.

“Don’t panic, but don’t ignore it,” he advised. “If you snore heavily, feel excessively sleepy in the daytime, or have long-term insomnia, it’s worth evaluation–not only for brain health but also for cardiovascular and metabolic health.”
